Classical.Structure: A double-membraned organelle, the 'powerhouse of the cell'. Contains its own DNA (mtDNA).
Classical.Function: Generates most of the cell's supply of adenosine triphosphate (ATP), used as a source of chemical energy. Also involved in signaling, cell death (apoptosis), and heat production.
Classical.Pathology: Mitochondrial disease, oxidative stress, role in aging and neurodegeneration.

SCPN.L1_QuantumBiological: The 'L1 Battery'. Provides the metabolic energy (ATP) required to create and sustain L1 coherence (e.g., Fröhlich pumping in D0.Microtubules). (Ref: Paper 1, Ch. 13)
SCPN.L2_NeurochemicalNeurological: The 'L2 Power Regulator'. ATP is itself an L2 neurotransmitter. Mitochondria also buffer L2 calcium signals, shaping synaptic transmission. (Ref: Paper 2)
SCPN.L3_GenomicEpigeneticMorphogenetic: Mitochondrial health (e.g., ROS signals) is a key L3 signal for apoptosis (programmed cell death), a core morphogenetic process.
SCPN.L4_CellularTissueSynchronisation: Mitochondria form dynamic, fused networks ('syncytia') that oscillate, synchronizing the L4 metabolic state of the entire cell and linking it to L4 neural firing. (Ref: Paper 1, Ch. 26)

Symbolic.MetaphysicalMapping: The 'Spark of Life'. An ancient, symbiotic entity that provides the 'fire' of metabolism, allowing matter to become conscious.

Falsification_Hypotheses: H1 (L1 Battery): A D0.Microtubule is shown to be L1 coherent (see D0.Microtubule.Validation.H1). Inhibiting mitochondrial ATP production (e.g., with oligomycin) will *fail* to disrupt this L1 coherence. This would falsify the L1 'metabolic pump' (Fröhlich) hypothesis.

H2 (L2 Ca-Buffer): A synaptic terminal (L2) is stimulated. Inhibiting mitochondrial calcium uptake (e.g., with Ru360) will *fail* to alter the L2 synaptic vesicle release probability. This would falsify the L2 'power regulator' (calcium buffering) hypothesis.
